Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language strengthens relationships and roles
Elaboration: Identifying the various communities to which they belong and how language reinforces membership of these communities, for example the intimate language of family members, the jargon of teenage groups, the technicality of some online communities, the language specific to recreational groups and the interaction patterns of the classroom

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language strengthens relationships and roles
Elaboration: Investigating language used by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors to reinforce relationships to Country/Place and with others, for example ‘Welcome’ for the Wurundjeri People is ‘Wominjeka’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and substantiation expresses individual views and values through language features such as allusion, evocative vocabulary and metaphor
Elaboration: Comparing texts that use evaluative language in different ways (for example, print advertisements, editorials, talkback radio, podcasts and poetry) and identifying wording that appraises indirectly through evocative language, similes and metaphors that direct readers’ views in particular ways

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore the ways that text structures and language features can be adapted and altered according to purpose
Elaboration: Comparing the use of linear and non-linear narratives in a range of short stories, and determining the purpose and effect of the different structures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore the ways that text structures and language features can be adapted and altered according to purpose
Elaboration: Comparing the opening paragraphs of different public texts such as feature articles, and determining the purpose and effect of the different structures and language features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how a range of cohesive devices, including nominalisation, condense information in texts and link, expand and sequence ideas
Elaboration: Sequencing and developing an argument using language structures that suggest conclusions (‘therefore’, ‘moreover’, ‘so’), give reasons (‘since’, ‘because’) or suggest conditionals (‘if … then’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore how authors vary sentence structures for effect, such as using a sentence fragment, or intentionally using a dependent clause on its own
Elaboration: Identifying the effects of using an interrupting clause inside another clause (for example, ‘His friend, who had left home the previous year, suddenly returned.’), intentionally using a dependent clause on its own (for example, ‘If you see what I mean.’) or using a sentence fragment (for example, ‘Breathtaking!’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how abstract nouns can be used to summarise ideas in text
Elaboration: Exploring sections of academic and technical texts, and analysing the use of abstract nouns (for example, ‘the previous argument’ or ‘the prologue’) to summarise and distil information, structure the argument and summarise preceding explanations

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how symbols in still and moving images and the use of sound augment meaning
Elaboration: Investigating the use of symbols (for example, specific seasons, weather and colours in images, films and picture books) and evaluating their contribution to viewers’ understanding, recognising that visual and verbal symbols have different meanings for different groups and cultures

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how symbols in still and moving images and the use of sound augment meaning
Elaboration: Understanding the use of symbols by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, where a symbol may have many meanings or have different meanings across language groups; for example, artwork enables the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander People from a particular Country/Place to identify symbols and interpret the artwork

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how symbols in still and moving images and the use of sound augment meaning
Elaboration: Exploring how recurring sounds or music make meaningful connections in text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how vocabulary choices contribute to style, mood and tone
Elaboration: Identifying the words used to create nuanced meaning; for example, identifying the words that create a sarcastic tone in a text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how vocabulary choices contribute to style, mood and tone
Elaboration: Identifying how the vocabulary used in a text contributes to its stylistic effectiveness

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand and use punctuation conventions to condense information and for referencing and citing others for formal and informal purposes
Elaboration: Understanding when to and how to cite in essays, reviews and academic assignments, and when it is appropriate to use direct quotations or to report sources more generally

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the representations of people and places in literary texts, drawn from diverse historical, cultural and social contexts, by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring and comparing representations of values of characters; for example, exploring the values associated with authority, community and family in literature drawn from different cultures and times

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the representations of people and places in literary texts, drawn from diverse historical, cultural and social contexts, by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Analysing how texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors reflect unique ways of being, knowing, thinking and doing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the representations of people and places in literary texts, drawn from diverse historical, cultural and social contexts, by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring the ways in which a wide range of Australian novels, poems and films represent water and characters’ relationships with water

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Explore and develop responses, including personal responses, to literary texts, comparing initial and subsequent impressions
Elaboration: Interrogating and making judgements about a text, comparing others’ ideas against their own and reaching an independent decision or consensus about the interpretations and ideas expressed

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Analyse how literary devices and language features, and still and moving images, shape an audience’s preference about the social, moral or ethical positions presented in literary texts
Elaboration: Reflecting on and discussing responses to literature (including characterisation, setting details, plot events, themes and literary devices used to achieve particular effects) and collaboratively formulating a list of factors that distinguish value

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the effect of text structures, language features and literary devices such as extended metaphor, metonymy, allegory, symbolism and intertextual references
Elaboration: Examining how different authors make use of devices such as imagery, and explaining the effect of these choices on audiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the effect of text structures, language features and literary devices such as extended metaphor, metonymy, allegory, symbolism and intertextual references
Elaboration: Identifying examples of literary devices in a range of poems and considering how they contribute to meaning and influence the emotional responses of the audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the ways that text structures, language features and literary devices in literary texts create aesthetic qualities
Elaboration: Comparing texts created by the same author to determine literary style, assessing their appeal and presenting comparisons to others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts, which may be hybrid, that experiment with literary text structures, language features and devices, and voice, for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Taking an existing short story, poem, play or speech in print form and creating a short film

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts, which may be hybrid, that experiment with literary text structures, language features and devices, and voice, for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Adapting traditional and contemporary literature through textual intervention, prequel or sequel

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to discuss opinions regarding texts that have different purposes and audiences, analysing how language features position an audience to respond in particular ways
Elaboration: Discussing how stereotypes are created through language and how they position listeners to respond

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to discuss opinions regarding texts that have different purposes and audiences, analysing how language features position an audience to respond in particular ways
Elaboration: Using effective strategies for dialogue and discussion in a range of formal and informal contexts, including speaking clearly and coherently and for an appropriate length of time, presenting an opinion and listening to the opinions of others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken texts for particular purposes, demonstrating different levels of formality in consideration of audience, using features of voice and multimodal or digital elements
Elaboration: Using graphics and text animations to accompany spoken text; for example, presenting a news item suitable for a current affairs program that uses images with spoken text to influence a viewer’s response

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken texts for particular purposes, demonstrating different levels of formality in consideration of audience, using features of voice and multimodal or digital elements
Elaboration: Selecting features of voice such as tone, volume, pitch and pace for their specific effects, to create tone or to persuade an audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use learnt knowledge to spell accurately and consistently, and understand that non-standard spelling is used in texts for particular effects, such as characterisation and humour, and to represent accents and distinctive speech
Elaboration: Exploring the spelling of neologisms and their effect in media texts such as online posts, for example ‘selfie’ and ‘Paralympics’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use learnt knowledge to spell accurately and consistently, and understand that non-standard spelling is used in texts for particular effects, such as characterisation and humour, and to represent accents and distinctive speech
Elaboration: Analysing how spelling is used to represent the distinctive speech of a character by noting where authors have dropped letters from words to emulate the sound of spoken words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how representations of people, places, events and concepts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Examining the representation of public figures in media and recognising how these vary in different contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how representations of people, places, events and concepts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and analysing how news is conveyed in texts; for example, analysing representations of an event at a particular time reported in the media

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how representations of people, places, events and concepts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Comparing texts from different time periods and analysing the language features used to represent individuals or groups

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to explicitly represent values, beliefs and attitudes
Elaboration: Analysing the use of language in the coverage of a contentious issue in a range of news services and social media

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to explicitly represent values, beliefs and attitudes
Elaboration: Explaining how authors use language features to represent ideas and convey opinions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to explicitly represent values, beliefs and attitudes
Elaboration: Comparing a range of advocacy, campaign or inspirational speeches from films or media and identifying language features that influence the listener

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the organisation of ideas in paragraphs and extended texts, and evaluate its impact on meaning
Elaboration: Evaluating techniques used in texts to organise ideas and evoke emotional responses, such as comparison, contrast, exaggeration, juxtaposition, the changing of chronological order, and the expansion and compression of time

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the organisation of ideas in paragraphs and extended texts, and evaluate its impact on meaning
Elaboration: Explaining whether the author conveys meaning effectively, through the sequence of information and evidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to compare and contrast ideas and opinions in and between texts
Elaboration: Comparing and contrasting visual representations of ideas, issues or events in online news reporting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to compare and contrast ideas and opinions in and between texts
Elaboration: Comparing representations of an event in print and digital sources, summarising their qualities, identifying opinions and analysing evidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to compare and contrast ideas and opinions in and between texts
Elaboration: Summarising articles representing a current event, comparing and contrasting ideas and opinions in and between texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, that present a point of view and advance, illustrate or expand ideas, including texts that integrate print, multimodal and/or digital elements in deliberate consideration of an audience
Elaboration: Developing an argument that has a series of sequenced and linked paragraphs, beginning with a contention, followed by a series of supported points that develop a line of argument, and a conclusion that summarises the main line of argument

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, that present a point of view and advance, illustrate or expand ideas, including texts that integrate print, multimodal and/or digital elements in deliberate consideration of an audience
Elaboration: Creating informative texts that explain and analyse complex phenomena using well-chosen facts and precise language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, that present a point of view and advance, illustrate or expand ideas, including texts that integrate print, multimodal and/or digital elements in deliberate consideration of an audience
Elaboration: Choosing text structures and adapting literary devices such as similes, metaphors and personification to meet the perceived needs of an audience when debating a topic, creating a voice over for a media presentation or presenting a seminar

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, that present a point of view and advance, illustrate or expand ideas, including texts that integrate print, multimodal and/or digital elements in deliberate consideration of an audience
Elaboration: Collaborating with peers to develop imaginative recreations of part of a text or to represent a key idea in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Review and edit their own texts and the texts of others to improve clarity, coherence and control over content, organisation, paragraphing, sentence structure, vocabulary and multimodal elements, and reflect on these processes
Elaboration: Editing by checking for run-on sentences, ensuring detail or repetition is used for effect, and ensuring paragraphs are linked in ways that develop the narrative

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Review and edit their own texts and the texts of others to improve clarity, coherence and control over content, organisation, paragraphing, sentence structure, vocabulary and multimodal elements, and reflect on these processes
Elaboration: Reviewing and editing their own and others’ texts, which may involve using online applications, for accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation, and to achieve particular purposes and address specific audiences by improving clarity and control of content through organising, developing, extending and linking ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Review and edit their own texts and the texts of others to improve clarity, coherence and control over content, organisation, paragraphing, sentence structure, vocabulary and multimodal elements, and reflect on these processes
Elaboration: Discussing, with a peer, choices of literary devices used in a literary text, and evaluating the potential effect of each choice on an audience
